HOW TO GET HERE


You can come to Greece by plane, road or by sea.


By plane 
By plane you will arrive at the Athens International Airport 'Eleftherios Venizelos' or one of the regional airports * in the country that serve, apart from local flights, direct flights from abroad and charter flights. The Athens International Airport serves daily hundreds of flights from all over the world. It is located 33 km from Athens city centre and is easily accessible by public transport or by car via Attiki Odos, which is the ring road of the wider metropolitan area of ​​Athens. There are frequent connections to the centre and various parts of the city and to the port of Piraeus, via metro, suburban railway and buses.

By boat 
The ports of the country welcome millions of visitors each year from all around the world. The most important of these are the ports of Piraeus, Patras, Igoumenitsa and Thessaloniki.


The port of Piraeus, at 15 km away from the city centre, is the main port of Athens and the main commercial port of the country. Ships depart from here to the Cyclades Islands, the Dodecanese, North Aegean, Crete, the Saronic Gulf, but also for international destinations on an everyday basis.


Other passenger ports of Attica, which serve some destinations in the Aegean, include Rafina, on the eastern coast of Attica (about 30 minutes from the city centre), and the port of Lavrio in the southernmost tip of Attica (about an hour from centre of the city).


The port of Patras (220 km from Athens via the National Road of Athens-Patras) is connected with ferry with Italy (ports of Ancona, Bari, Venice and Trieste), with daily routes, bringing about half of the total international traffic of the country.


Greece is also connected to Turkey through six ports of the Aegean. Specifically, on a daily basis many itineraries are conducted such as Mytilene-Ayvalik, Chios-Cesme, Samos - Kusadasi and Kos - Kusadasi while frequent routes link Rhodes with Bodrum and Marmaris as well as Kalymnos with Marmaris.


By train 
The Greek railway network connects the North and South parts of the country, and especially Athens, Patras and Thessaloniki, as well as Greece with the Balkan countries, and subsequently to the rest of Europe. The routes are operated on a regular daily basis with the Intercity type of trains (express trains) and conventional trains.


Greece is connected by rail with Bulgaria, Serbia and Macedonia through the services of Thessaloniki-Sofia and Thessaloniki-Skopje-Belgrade. The itineraries are daily, with one train a day to and from Thessaloniki.


By car 
Many visitors choose to enter the country by road, through Albania, Bulgaria, FYROM and Turkey, but also from Italy using the ferry link between the two countries. The entrance gates to Greece, in the northern and eastern land borders of the country, are: Exochi in Drama for Bulgaria, Eyzonoi of Kilkis for FYROM, Kakavia of Ioannina for Albania and Kipoi of Evros for Turkey.


International Driving Permit is required for all drivers who are not citizens of the European Union, along with the official license of the country.
